com.github.thorbenkuck.netcom2.network.shared

Interface Session

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Mutex, Serializable

    public interface Session
extends Mutex, Serializable
    This interface describes a Session of any Network-Object.

    On the ClientStart side, this object is maintained, as long, as the ClientStart stays connected to the Server.

    On the ServerStart side, this object is maintained within an Client and shared across all Connection between each of the Connections of the Client.

    If you wanted to, you could create an custom Session-Class and provide it to an Client using Client.setSession(Session). Note that especially the behaviour of the methods triggerPrimation(), primed() and newPrimation() should NOT be changed to maintain the Behaviour of the internal Mechanisms. Otherwise you might break the core Mechanisms between Client-Server-Communication or Connection establishment.

    Otherwise you can feel free to create an custom Session.

    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    1.0
    See Also:
    Client, Connection, ReceiveFamily, CommunicationRegistration

    • Method Detail

      • createNew

        static Session createNew(Client client)
        Returns a new instance of the internal implementation of this interface.

        Based upon the given client, a SendBridge-implementation will be created to allow the Session to send objects.

        The use of this Method is encouraged over instantiating the internal Session manually! The internal Implementation might change due to development reasons and might be swapped easy without breaking code using this method

        Parameters:
        client - the Client, which is connected to the Session
        Returns:
        an instance of the internal Session implementation

      • isIdentified

        boolean isIdentified()
        Describes whether or not this Session is identified

        Value is controlled via setIdentified(boolean) The Default value for this is: false

        Returns:
        if the session is identified

      • setIdentified

        void setIdentified(boolean identified)
        Sets this Sessions identification value.

        It regulates the output of isIdentified()

        Parameters:
        identified - the new boolean value

      • getIdentifier

        String getIdentifier()
        Returns the unique identifier of this Session.

        Value is controlled via setIdentifier(String) The Default value for this is: UUID.randomUUID() created inside of the SessionImpl constructor

        Returns:
        the Identifier of this Session

      • setIdentifier

        void setIdentifier(String identifier)
        Sets this Sessions identifier value.

        It regulates the output of getIdentifier()

        Parameters:
        identifier - the new Identifier for this particular Session

      • getProperties

        Properties getProperties()
        Returns the internal Properties instance.

        This instance might be shared across multiple Sessions, but it is discouraged to send this instance to an ClientStart. Value is controlled via setProperties(Properties) The Default value for this is: new Properties()

        Returns:
        the internal set of Properties

      • setProperties

        void setProperties(Properties properties)
        Sets this Sessions internal Properties instance.

        It regulates the output of getProperties()

        Parameters:
        properties - the new Properties instance that this Session will use

      • send

        void send(Object o)
        Sends an Object over the Network.

        This Method utilizes an SendBridge to send the given Object to the Server. This Method does no Sanity-Checks, neither does it work asynchronously! Its return depends completely on the implementation of the corresponding Client and the corresponding Connection.

        The mechanisms of Serialization, Encryption, s.o. therefor also depend on the corresponding Client and the corresponding Connection.

        Since this Method is not offering an Parameter to choose the Connection, the chosen Connection will be the Clients DefaultConnection, which is initialized at the first connect of the corresponding ClientStart.

        This Method waits for the Primation of the corresponding Client and therefor of this Session.

        Parameters:
        o - the Object that should be send over the Network.

      • eventOf

        <T> com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.pipe.Pipeline<T> eventOf(Class<T> clazz)
        Prepares and returns an Pipeline instance for an given Class.

        Those Events can be handled as you like. Since the returned Value is an Pipeline, you can edit as you like. Note that after an Pipeline has been created, you cannot delete it! You can clear the existing instance, but you cannot free up the memory space of that Pipeline

        An event, encapsulated inside such an Pipeline can than be triggered using triggerEvent(Class, Object).

        Type Parameters:
        T - Generic type about the type, which this Pipeline is going to handle
        Parameters:
        clazz - The Class, of which the Event is about
        Returns:
        An Pipeline-implementation, to add or modify the Event

      • triggerEvent

        <T> void triggerEvent(Class<T> clazz,
                      T t)
        Triggers an before set Event, using eventOf(Class).

        It searches for an corresponding Pipeline and if present runs it. If it cannot find an Pipeline a.e. no Event has been registered, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

        The class is required, because of Javas type-erasure. Because t.getClass(), does not return an Class of the Type of the Object, but of ? extends Object.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the Type of the Pipeline
        Parameters:
        clazz - the Identifier Class for this event
        t - an Object instance of the Class
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if no Pipeline is set

      • addHeartBeat

        void addHeartBeat(HeartBeat<Session> heartBeat)
        Adds and holds an HeartBeat, which handles any Session.

        Note that this method does not create an HeartBeat, it accepts any Instance of an HeartBeat and starts it asynchronous. Other than maintaining and running said HearBeat, this method and the Session in total does nothing else with an HeartBeat!

        Parameters:
        heartBeat - the HeartBeat that should be added to this Session

      • removeHeartBeat

        void removeHeartBeat(HeartBeat<Session> heartBeat)
        Removes an previously set HeartBeat instance, using the addHeartBeat(HeartBeat) method.
        Parameters:
        heartBeat - the HeartBeat that should be removed from this Session

      • triggerPrimation

        void triggerPrimation()
        This method is only used by the Client. The Primation is an internal Mechanism, to check the State, whether or not the current Session is ready to be used. As any new Client is created, it gets an new Instance of a Session, which by default is not primed. Than, after the Handshake between the ClientStart and the ServerStart, the Client is going to be Primed by calling Client.triggerPrimation(). This results in this Method being called. Internally, this method is further used whenever an new Connection is successfully established.

        The use of this method is not forbidden, but discouraged since this might screw up the internal mechanisms

      • primed

        Awaiting primed()
        Returns the internal state, whether or not this Session is primed. This state is represented via the Awaiting interface and you can await it, by calling Awaiting.synchronize().

        This instance of Awaiting will continue, once triggerPrimation() is called.

        Returns:
        The internal state, whether or not this Session is primed.

      • newPrimation

        void newPrimation()
        Resets the internal primed state. This resets the Internal Awaiting.

        The use of this Method is certainly not forbidden, but discouraged. Calling this method might screw up the internal mechanisms.

      • update

        SessionUpdater update()
        This is a functional style of updating the Session.

        If you use this on the Client-Side, note that calling SessionUpdater.sendOverNetwork() will NOT update the Session on the Server-Side

        Returns:
        a new SessionUpdater instance for you to use.
